thread.title: Highest paid college coaches in Texas

author: chron.com
title: Highest paid college coaches in Texas
text:

Record at Texas State : 18-22 2015 Salary : $425,000

Note on APR : Academic Progress Rate (APR) holds institutions accountable for the academic progress of their student-athletes through a team-based metric that accounts for the eligibility and retention of each student-athlete for each academic term

Record at Rice : 50-56 2015 Salary :... Image 6 of 38 6. Tom Herman - Houston
Record at Houston : 4-0 2015 Salary : $1,450,000
Bonus Money N/A - First year as head coach at Houston.
Income Notes School pay includes $100,000 that annually accrues to Herman if he remains head coach on Dec. 31. Three years' worth of these amounts will vest to Herman if he remains head coach on Feb. 28, 2018. That money, plus any additional annual amounts, will become payable if he is fired without cause after that date, or he will receive $500,000 if he completes his contract Feb. 29, 2020

Photo: Dave Martin, STF No. 1 – Nick Saban | Alabama Total Pay: $7,160,187 Staff Combined... Image 38 of 38 Highest paid college football coaches in Texas 1 / 38 Back to Gallery If you needed a reminder that college football — college athletics, in general — has become an arms race, look no further than USA Today's recently released list of FBS college football coaching salaries .
The amount of money on display, from No. 1 (Nick Saban, Alabama) to No. 121 (Todd Berry, Lousiana-Monroe), is staggering.
Four coaches hailing from Texas schools rank among the top 20: Charlie Strong, Kevin Sumlin, Art Briles and Gary Patterson.
RELATED: Salaries of Greater Houston Area football coaches
According to USA Today sports projects reporter and editor Steve Berkowitz, the number of FBS football head coaches making at least $3 million has near quintupled in the past half-decade, from 7 in 2010 to 34 this season.
Some of these amounts exceed even what NFL head coaches make. San Francisco 49ers coach Jim Tomsula makes $3.5 million a year; that would place him just 25th among all FBS coaches.
The tactical proliferation of FBS programs extends far beyond inflated coaching salaries though, especially among the Power Five conferences.
Texas A&M just spent over $450 million on renovations to Kyle Field.
Texas signed a 20-year agreemen t with ESPN for the Longhorn Network in 2011, which nets the university $10,980,000 per year, with an annual increase of three percent.
Oregon's athletic revenue nearly touched $200 million in 2014.
Auburn spent $126 million last year, despite bringing in just over $113 million.
All this in the pursuit of teenagers and, with the unpalatable way recruiting has evolved, preteens.
It's a troubling contest which has left the National Collegiate Athletic Association and many of its 128 FBS schools looking less like "amateur" organizations and more like professional football teams.
Click through the slideshow above to see where each coach of a Texas university ranks.
nmoyle@express-news.net
t witter.com/nrmoyle
